strategic_profile.executive_summary: The University of New Hampshire (UNH) is a public land-grant, sea-grant, and space-grant research university. Known for its strong undergraduate liberal arts and sciences programs, as well as significant contributions in oceanography, marine biology, and environmental conservation. It serves as a flagship institution for the state of New Hampshire.
strategic_profile.market_position: Regional public research university with strong marine and environmental science programs.
strategic_profile.admissions_philosophy: UNH seeks intellectually curious and community-minded students who will contribute to a vibrant academic and social environment. A holistic review process considers academic performance, extracurricular involvement, essays, and recommendations, looking for potential to succeed and thrive in a research-intensive setting.

analyst_takeaways.takeaway: Strong regional brand recognition, especially in specialized science fields.
Opportunity to further leverage its unique geographic location for experiential learning and research.
Potential for growth in graduate programs, building on existing research strengths.
Admissions strategy should highlight career outcomes in growing sectors tied to its academic specializations.

campus_dynamics.social_environment: Lively campus culture with a strong sense of community, particularly appealing to students interested in outdoor activities and Greek life. Numerous clubs and organizations foster a diverse range of interests.
campus_dynamics.transportation_impact: Located in a small college town, Durham is walkable/bikeable for most students. Public transit within campus and to nearby towns is available but limited. Many students bring cars, especially upperclassmen, due to the rural setting.
campus_dynamics.research_impact: High research activity, particularly notable in marine sciences (Jackson Estuarine Laboratory, Coastal Marine Lab), environmental studies, and space science. Undergraduate research opportunities are extensive and integrated into many programs.

current_status.test_policy_details: The University of New Hampshire is test-optional, meaning applicants are not required to submit SAT or ACT scores for admission. This policy has been in place since Fall 2020. More weight is given to a student's individual high school performance than standardized test scores. While scores are not required for admission, students who took a standardized test and enroll at UNH will be required to submit their results for university research purposes only; these scores will not influence the admission decision. Homeschooled students and those attending nontraditional schools are also eligible for the test-optional program and are encouraged to provide detailed curriculum information or supporting documents.

longitudinal_trends.notes: Admissions data for Fall 2025 (Class of 2029) is not yet finalized or publicly released. Figures for applications, admits, and enrollment are not available at this time.
Data for the 2024-2025 academic year, representing Fall 2024 admissions. Enrolled total refers to first-year students on the Durham campus.
Data for Fall 2023 admissions. The acceptance rate for 2023 was reported as 86.8%.
Data for Fall 2022 admissions. Acceptance rate for 2022 was reported as 86.9%.

gpa.notes: The University of New Hampshire reports an average weighted GPA of 3.52, with a 25th percentile of 3.11 and a 75th percentile of 3.91. For unweighted GPAs, the average is 3.3, with a 25th percentile of 3.0 and a 75th percentile of 3.6. This information reflects the competitive academic profile of incoming students. No specific data was found regarding '89% in top 10% of class'.

testing.policy_note: University of New Hampshire is test-optional. Students are not required to submit SAT or ACT scores for admission. UNH considers the highest section scores across all SAT/ACT test dates submitted (superscore policy).

demographics.notes: Legacy defined as alumni children. 20% applies to the UNH Durham campus.

men.note: Data for Fall 2023 first-time, first-year (freshmen) students.

women.note: Data for Fall 2023 first-time, first-year (freshmen) students.

application_deadlines.notes: Students applying under Early Action receive an admission decision prior to the end of January and have until May 1 to enroll.
Applicants under Regular Decision receive an admission decision prior to the end of March.

supplemental_requirements.details: No supplemental essays or writing prompts are required beyond the essay submitted as part of the Common Application.

supplemental_requirements.deadline: March 1, 2026 (for Fall 2026 admittance); November 8, 2025 (recommended for Early Action applicants)
supplemental_requirements.details: An audition is required for all undergraduate music majors. This includes a written theory diagnostic test covering intervals, triads, and major and minor scales, and a performance on your major instrument. Instrumentalists should prepare two contrasting pieces or etudes and demonstrate scale proficiency. Vocalists should sing one English Art Song and one Italian selection (preferably from the '24 Italian Songs & Arias' anthology), both memorized, and be prepared for sight-reading. Jazz Guitarists must submit a pre-audition MP3 recording before a live audition is scheduled (deadline for submission: February 2, 2024 for 2024-2025, check for current year updates).

Students pursuing a Composition option must submit a music portfolio containing scores of at least three varied works for different groups of instruments or voices, in addition to an audition on their major instrument.

supplemental_requirements.target_program: Studio Art (B.A. in Studio Art or B.A. in Studio Art/Art Education)
supplemental_requirements.deadline: February 1 (for incoming freshmen); November 15 (for spring semester transfer students); April 1 (for fall semester transfer students)
supplemental_requirements.details: A portfolio is required for all prospective new students, including external transfers, wishing to pursue a B.A. in Studio Art or B.A. in Studio Art/Art Education. The portfolio should reflect your strongest work, include 10 to 12 samples of your best work, with at least four to five pieces being drawings from direct observation. Portfolio images should be sent as individual JPEG attachments (1-2MB each, max 24MB total) in one email to art-arthistory@unh.edu. The body of the email should include required information.

supplemental_requirements.target_program: Theatre & Dance (Musical Theatre Option, Acting & Directing Option, etc.)
supplemental_requirements.details: An initial video audition is required. Callbacks will be done in person. Specific requirements vary by option: for non-musicals, one 60-90 second dramatic monologue and one 60-90 second comedic monologue. For musicals, specific song cutting requirements (e.g., 16-32 bar cut in the style of the show) and a monologue are needed. Auditions are submitted via Acceptd.

holistic_factors.specific_differentiators: Strong emphasis on high school academic performance, including rigor of coursework and GPA, as indicators of college-level success.

major_selection_tactics: Consider applying to a less competitive major if your top choice is highly selective. Some programs at UNH are designated as 'competitive majors,' including health sciences, kinesiology, occupational therapy, nursing, and certain majors within the Paul College of Business and Economics. These may have limited capacity or specific prerequisites. Applying to a less competitive major, if you're not fully set on a highly competitive field, might increase your chances of admission to the university, with the possibility to explore other interests later.

Apply as undeclared to explore options. A significant portion of first-year students (around 28%) enter UNH as undeclared. Students have until the second semester of their sophomore year to officially declare a major, providing ample time to take various courses and explore different fields before committing. UNH offers resources like academic advisors and a dedicated seminar (COLA 401) to assist undeclared students in finding their path.

If you have a general interest area, consider being undeclared within a specific college. For instance, if you are interested in health-related fields but unsure of a specific major, you can apply undeclared within the College of Health and Human Services. This allows you to explore the majors and career pathways available within that broader area with tailored advising and programs.

Research major-specific admission requirements and consider early action for competitive programs. For competitive majors, applying early action can provide priority consideration. It's crucial to investigate if your desired major has additional application requirements, such as portfolios or auditions, and to prepare accordingly.

Be aware that some majors have lower acceptance rates. While the overall acceptance rate for UNH is 87%, individual program acceptance rates can vary, particularly for competitive fields. Understanding which majors are more difficult to get into can help you strategize your application and prepare for the academic rigor expected in those programs.
college_ranking_tactics: Highlight specific top-ranked majors and programs within the university's colleges (e.g., Biological & Biomedical Sciences, Psychology, Environmental Science, Business).
Emphasize overall 'Best Value' public university status and improved national university rankings, which reflect student success metrics like graduation rates and faculty research.
Showcase strong faculty-student relationships, hands-on learning, and research opportunities available within specific colleges and programs.
Promote academic flexibility, such as the option to start undeclared and the availability of robust advising services, to help students navigate program choices.
Detail specific admission requirements and coursework expectations for competitive majors within different colleges to guide prospective students.
application_strategy.alternate_major_strategy: advice_on_selecting_backup_alternate_majors: ["Consider a related, less competitive major: If your first-choice major is highly competitive, research other majors within the same college or a related field that might have less stringent initial admission requirements. For example, if you're interested in a competitive health-related field within the College of Health and Human Services (CHHS) but aren't initially admitted, you might enter CHHS as an undeclared student. Professional academic counselors are available to help these students explore health sciences opportunities and determine appropriate major courses.", "Embrace an 'Undeclared' status: UNH recognizes that many students are undecided when they apply, with about 28% of incoming first-year students being undeclared. The university encourages this thoughtful approach, offering resources like the COLA 401 class, which helps students explore major, career, and internship options, and regular meetings with academic advisors to build an academic plan. This can be a strategic backup, allowing you to fulfill general education requirements while preparing for an internal transfer to your preferred major.", 'Contact Admissions for guidance: If you know you want to change your major even before the fall semester begins, you can contact the UNH Admissions Office to discuss your options.']; internal_transfer_difficulty_for_competitive_majors: {'competitive_enrollment_restrictions': 'Some majors have competitive enrollment restrictions for incoming first-year students.', 'prerequisites_and_gpa': 'To internally transfer into a competitive major, students typically need to fulfill specific coursework and achieve a particular cumulative GPA. For example: Health Sciences (BS): Requires successful completion of Biomedical Science (BMS) 507 and 508, a cumulative GPA of 3.00 or higher, and a letter of interest. Applications are accepted during the spring semester with an April 15th deadline. Nursing: A cumulative GPA of 3.2 or higher is strongly recommended, along with the completion or current enrollment in Biomedical Science 507, Biomedical Science 508, Psychology 401, and English 401. The application also requires grade reports and an essay, and an interview may be necessary. Other CHHS majors like Communication Sciences & Disorders, Exercise Science, and Health Management & Policy also have specific GPA and course requirements for transfer.', 'limited_space': 'Admission to these competitive programs as an internal transfer is competitive and can be very limited. Students interested in competitive BS degree programs, such as those in Health Sciences, should consult with the appropriate Department program coordinator for specific admissions information.'}

financials.notes: University of New Hampshire is Need-Aware. The average need-based aid package includes $9,556 in grants/scholarships and $6,557 in loans. The Granite Guarantee provides free tuition for Pell-eligible New Hampshire residents, but it does not cover all costs (fees, housing, food, or books). There is no explicit 'no loans for families under $75K' policy mentioned in the search results.

scholarships.name: Presidential Scholarship
scholarships.amount: Varies (range of $5,000 to $20,000/year mentioned for a related scholarship)
scholarships.benefits: Awarded based on academic achievement, rigor of courses, leadership, extracurricular engagement, and community involvement.

scholarships.name: Hamel Scholarship

scholarships.name: UNH Alumni Association Legacy Scholarship
scholarships.deadline: Varies (application for review even if final decision not made)
scholarships.benefits: Renewable for four years with a 3.2 GPA; recognizes strong leadership, academic record, and extracurricular interests. Awarded to a direct descendant of a UNH alumnus/a.

scholarships.name: Honors College Annual Scholarships
scholarships.benefits: Additional awards for qualifying Honors students, based on academic achievement, contributions to UNH and Honors College, financial need, and/or donor-specified factors.
scholarships.application_method: Separate Application (eligible Honors College students in their second year or later are invited to apply)

ap_policy.general_rule: A score of 3 or higher grants credit for many exams, but some exams, particularly in subjects like Calculus, Computer Science, and certain Physics, often require a score of 4 or 5.
exceptions: AP Computer Science A and Computer Science Principles credit may not count toward the Computer Science or Engineering major.
For Physics, credit can be granted for either the Physics 1 & 2 exams or the Physics C exams, but not both.
Students taking both Calculus AB and BC exams will not receive duplicate credit for Math 425.
Statistics credit may be used to satisfy the 'Quantitative Reasoning' requirement unless it is a required course for a student's major.
AP Research and AP Seminar typically award elective credit for a score of 3 or higher.
ap_policy.usage: AP credits can be used for advanced placement in courses, to fulfill some major or minor program requirements, and to satisfy the University's Discovery Program (General Education) requirements, or as general elective credit. Students should review their degree audit to confirm how transfer credit has been applied.

ib_policy.general_rule: HL exams with scores of 5, 6, or 7 grant 8 credits each, except for Higher Level Art/Design, film, and Business/Management. Standard Level exams do not receive credit.

transfer_articulation.restrictions: Maximum of 96 transfer credits toward a bachelor's degree, with a limit of 72 credits from associate-level work toward a bachelor's degree (exceptions apply for CPS-Manchester and Thompson School of Applied Science students). A minimum grade of C- or higher is required for courses to be considered for transfer credit, and credits must be from a regionally accredited institution. Transfer credits do not calculate into the UNH GPA. For the College of Professional Studies, bachelor's degree programs accept a maximum of 90 credits and associate degree programs accept a maximum of 44 credits.

what_it_takes: Strong academic record with challenging coursework
Meaningful extracurricular activities and community involvement
essay_tips: Be specific about why UNH and your chosen major Your essay should clearly articulate *why* you've chosen a particular major and *why* you want to study it specifically at the University of New Hampshire. This means doing your research and mentioning specific programs, courses, or resources that align with your interests, demonstrating that this essay could *only* be about you and *only* about UNH.

Show, don't tell, through storytelling Instead of simply stating your qualities or interests, use concrete examples and narratives to illustrate them. Craft your essay as a story with a beginning, middle and end, taking the reader on a journey and allowing them to see your passions in action through specific scenes and details.

Tell *your* unique story Focus on what makes you stand out and share something about yourself, your life, or your story that isn't evident in other parts of your application. The best essays tell a normal story in a special way that reflects your growth and perspective.

Connect your interests to specific resources at the school Actively research UNH and identify specific aspectswhether it's a particular club, research opportunity, professor, or unique programthat genuinely excite you. Then, connect your personal interests and aspirations to these specific offerings, showing that you've thought deeply about how you would thrive and contribute to the UNH community.
red_flags: Grade decline senior year or a low cumulative GPA, especially below 2.8 or 3.0 for competitive majors like business and science.
Generic essays that do not tell your unique story, convey your personality, or explain any circumstances that might have impacted academic performance.
Listing extracurricular activities without demonstrating depth, impact, or how you will contribute to the UNH community.
Poor letters of recommendation from individuals who do not know you well enough to advocate for your strengths, weaknesses, and potential for success.
Not demonstrating continued academic challenge and leadership during your senior year.

insights.insight: UNH is a moderately selective institution with an acceptance rate typically in the high 80s (around 87-88%).
UNH offers extensive undergraduate research opportunities, even for first-year students, and is particularly strong in environmental and marine sciences.
The University of New Hampshire has consistently been recognized as a 'Best Value Public University in New England', with a high percentage of first-year students receiving financial assistance.
UNH emphasizes a vibrant campus life with over 200 student clubs and organizations, fostering a strong sense of community despite its rural location.

outcomes.notes: Median earnings 10 years after enrollment are $66,479. Median earnings 6 years after enrollment are $42,200. The employment rate 2 years after graduation could not be found in the provided search results from the College Scorecard or other direct sources. First destination survey data indicates employment rates immediately after graduation, such as 77% for the Class of 2022.
